QC.Lic01.description: Is code licensed to be freely used, modified and distributed by others?

evidence.success: An Open Source license found in the code repository: %s
evidence.failure: No Open Source license found in the code repository

QC.Lic01.hint:
Your source code repository shall be distributed under an open source license for this subcriterion to pass successfully. Be sure to have a license file present in the code repository matching the name LICENSE with optional extensions (depending on the format used): [.md|.rst|.txt].

Valid licenses are any of those approved either by the Open Source Initiative and/or the Free Software Foundation . You can also check the choosealicense.com site

QC.Lic01.1.description: Is LICENSE file placed in the root path of the code repository?

evidence.success: LICENSE file is visible at the root path of the code repository: %s
evidence.failure: LICENSE file is not placed at the root path of the code repository: %s

QC.Lic01.1.hint: Most social coding platforms require the license file to placed in the root path of the code repository, so it is a good practice to use this location by default. Allowed file names are LICENSE, LICENSE.md, LICENSE.rst, LICENSE.txt

QC.Lic02.description: Does the code use a license approved by Open Source Initiative?

evidence.success: License <%s> is approved by the Open Source Initiative
evidence.failure: License <%s> is not approved by the Open Source Initiative

QC.Lic02.hint: The Open Source Initiative (OSI) sets out the requirements for software to be legally declared as Open Source. The license in use shall be in the list of OSI-approved licenses for this criterion to be successful

QC.Lic02.1.description: Does the code use an Open Source Initiative's popular-recognized license?

evidence.success: License <%s> is listed under the Open Source Initiative popular category
evidence.failure: License <%s> is not listed under the Open Source Initiative popular category

QC.Lic02.1.hint: The Open Source Initiative (OSI) sets out the requirements for software to be legally declared as Open Source. OSI provides a list of popular licenses that shall match most of the demands. The license in use shall be in the list of OSI popular licenses for this criterion to be successful
